heliolib.solar_tools package

Submodules

heliolib.solar_tools.get_solar_path module

class heliolib.solar_tools.get_solar_path.GetSolarPath(latitude, longitude, datetime_index: DatetimeIndex)[source]

Bases: object

GetSolarPath class is designed to calculate solar position parameters (azimuth, elevation, zenith) based on the provided latitude, longitude, and datetime index using the pvlib library.

Parameters:

  • latitudefloat

    Latitude of the location in decimal degrees.

  • longitudefloat

    Longitude of the location in decimal degrees.

  • datetime_indexpd.DatetimeIndex

    Datetime index for which solar position parameters are to be calculated.

Raises:

  • ValueError: If latitude or longitude is not a float, or if latitude is not between -90 and 90 degrees, or if longitude is not between -180 and 180 degrees, or if the datetime_index is empty.

Method:

  • solar_path_parameterpandas.DataFrame

    On this method call it will return pandas.DataFrame of Azimuth, Zenith and Elevation.

Examples:

INPUT:-

## Datetime Index with timezone aware datetime_asia_kolkata = pd.date_range(start=’2023-12-11’, end=’2023-12-12’, freq=’5T’, tz=’Asia/Kolkata’) ## Object of the GetSolarPath object = GetSolarPath(latitude=28.613939, longitude=77.209023, datetime_index=datetime_asia_kolkata)

OUTPUT:-
datetime | azimuth | elevation | zenith |

|-------------------------|———–|------------|————| | 2023-12-11 00:00:00+05:30 | 330.318709| -83.513521 | 173.513521 | | 2023-12-11 00:05:00+05:30 | 340.007818| -83.976017 | 173.976017 | | 2023-12-11 00:10:00+05:30 | 350.920119| -84.252760 | 174.252760 | | 2023-12-11 00:15:00+05:30 | 2.477379 | -84.316526 | 174.316526 | | 2023-12-11 00:20:00+05:30 | 13.853868 | -84.160331 | 174.160331 |

solar_path_parameter()[source]

Calculates solar position parameters (azimuth, elevation, zenith) for the stored datetime index, latitude, and longitude.

Returns:

  • pd.DataFrame: Solar position parameters (azimuth, elevation, zenith) for each timestamp in the datetime index.

heliolib.solar_tools.sunrise_sunset_time module

class heliolib.solar_tools.sunrise_sunset_time.SunTimes(latitude: float, longitude: float)[source]

Bases: object

A class to calculate the sunrise and sunset times for a given latitude and longitude.

The SunTimes class uses astral’s LocationInfo and sun functions to determine sunrise and sunset times based on the provided geographical coordinates. It handles both specific date queries and defaults to the current date if none is provided.

Attributes:

location (LocationInfo):

An astral LocationInfo object representing the geographical location.

Methods:

get_sun_times(specific_date=None, return_datetime=False):

Returns the sunrise and sunset times as UTC aware python datetime or time object for the specified date or today’s date.

Raises:

ValueError:

If the provided latitude or longitude are out of the valid range.

Example: # Initialize with New York City coordinates sun_times = SunTimes(40.7128, -74.0060)

# Get today’s sunrise and sunset times sunrise, sunset = sun_times.get_sun_times() print(“Today’s Sunrise:”, sunrise) print(“Today’s Sunset:”, sunset)

# Get sunrise and sunset for a specific date sunrise, sunset = sun_times.get_sun_times(“2023-01-01”) print(“Sunrise on 2023-01-01:”, sunrise) print(“Sunset on 2023-01-01:”, sunset)

get_sun_times(specific_date: str | None = None, return_datetime: bool = False)[source]

Get the sunrise and sunset times for either the current date or a specified date.

Parameters:

specific_date: (str, optional):

A string representing a specific date in “YYYY-MM-DD” format. Defaults to None, in which case today’s date is used.

return_datetime (bool, optional):

Flag to determine the format of the returned times. If True, returns full datetime objects. If False, returns time in ‘HH:MM’ format. Defaults to False.

Returns:

tuple: A tuple containing the sunrise and sunset times as UTC aware python datetime or time object. Times are formatted as ‘YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:00+00:00’. if return_datetime is True, or ‘HH:MM:00+00:00’ if False.

Raises:

ValueError: If the specific_date_str is not in the correct format. Exception: If there’s an error in calculating sunrise and sunset times.

Example:

# Example usage for getting times for London on a specific date london_sun_times = SunTimes(51.5074, -0.1278) sunrise, sunset = london_sun_times.get_sun_times(“2023-06-21”) print(“Sunrise in London on 2023-06-21:”, sunrise) print(“Sunset in London on 2023-06-21:”, sunset)

# Example usage with return_datetime flag sunrise, sunset = london_sun_times.get_sun_times(“2023-06-21”, return_datetime=True) print(“Full datetime for sunrise in London on 2023-06-21:”, sunrise) print(“Full datetime for sunset in London on 2023-06-21:”, sunset)

heliolib.solar_tools.test_sunrise_sunset_time.test_sunrise_sunset_time_initialization_invalid()[source]

Test the initialization of the SunTimes class with invalid latitude and longitude.

This function tests the initialization of the SunTimes class with both valid and invalid latitude and longitude values. It uses assertions and pytest.raises to verify that the correct exceptions are raised and the error messages are as expected.

Parameters:

None

Returns:

None
